query: What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?
relevant_summary: Several actions can increase soil organic matter on agricultural land. Growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows has been shown to increase soil organic matter in controlled trials (Action 897). Using crop rotation, particularly when legumes are included, increases soil organic matter according to replicated trials from multiple countries (Action 857). Adding below-ground organic matter through compost and manure applications increases soil organic matter content, with controlled trials showing positive effects from amendments with manures and agricultural composts (Action 911), as well as mixed organic and inorganic amendments (Action 902). Growing green manure crops increases soil organic carbon according to controlled studies (Action 908). Changing tillage practices to reduced tillage or no-tillage systems maintains or increases soil organic matter, with fifteen studies showing maintained or increased soil organic matter under reduced tillage (Action 906). Additionally, amending soil with bacteria or fungi, specifically arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, has been found to increase soil organic matter content in controlled trials (Action 888).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: Four randomized, replicated trials from Canada, Portugal and Zambia measured the effect of including legumes in crop rotations and found the number of microbes and diversity of different soil animals increased.
Erosion: One randomized, replicated trial from Canada found that including forage crops in crop rotations reduced rainwater runoff and soil loss, and one replicated trial from Syria showed that including legumes in rotation increased water infiltration (movement of water into the soil).
Soil organic carbon: Four studies from Australia, Canada, and Denmark (including two controlled replicated trials and one replicated site comparison study), found increased soil organic carbon under crop rotation, particularly when some legumes were included.
Soil organic matter: Three of five replicated trials from Canada, Portugal and Syria (one also randomized, one also controlled and randomized), and one trial from the Philippines found increased soil organic matter, particularly when legumes were included in the rotation. One study found lower soil organic matter levels when longer crop rotations were used. One randomized, replicated study found no effect on soil particle size.
Soils covered: Clay, clay-loam, fine clay, loam, loam/silt loam, sandy clay, sandy loam, silty clay, silty loam."
}

Drought: Three replicated trials from Europe and India (one also randomized) found the size of soil cracks decreased, and ability of soil to absorb water and soil water content increased with conventional ploughing and sub-soiling. 
Erosion: Nine replicated trials from Brazil, Europe, India, Nigeria and the USA, and one review showed mixed results of tillage on soil erosion. Four trials (including two replicated and two site comparison studies) found higher nutrient retention under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till compared to conventionally tilled soil, but conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial and one replicated trial found mixed effects of reduced tillage on soil nitrogen levels.
Yield: One replicated study from Canada found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage compared to conventional tillage, and one controlled, randomized, replicated study from the USA found higher yields when subsoiling was done. One randomized, replicated study from Portugal found no effect of tillage treatment on yield.

query: Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?
relevant_summary: Actions that have been found beneficial for increasing soil organism diversity include reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use (Action 904), which showed higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in low-input systems based on two site comparison studies from Italy and Pakistan. Converting to organic farming (Action 895) demonstrated higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity of soil organisms in four studies across Asia, Europe, and the USA. Using crop rotation (Action 857) increased the number of microbes and diversity of different soil animals in four randomized, replicated trials from Canada, Portugal and Zambia, particularly when legumes were included in the rotations. Changing tillage practices (Action 906) showed mixed results, with four of eleven studies finding more microbes, more species of earthworm, or higher microbe activity under reduced tillage. Excluding grazers from areas (Action 2309) was found to increase nematode diversity in one controlled study. Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding/planting (Action 3429) was tested in five studies, though results focused more on vegetation responses rather than soil organism diversity.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies examined the effects of inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding/planting on grassland vegetation. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Germany.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY (1 STUDY)

Overall richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi and sowing seeds of grassland species did not alter plant species richness.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE (4 STUDIES)

Overall abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi before sowing seeds initially increased vegetation cover, but after three years, vegetation cover did not differ between areas that were and were not inoculated. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the overall cover of herbaceous species.
Characteristic plant abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that adding mycorrhiza to the soil and sowing seeds of grassland species increased the abundance of target species that were considered a local conservation priority. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs increased the cover of three of 38 native prairie species.
Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the cover of woody species.
Native/non-target species abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not alter the biomass of three native grass and forb species.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE (1 STUDY)

Height (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds increased the height of giant sacaton plants.
Individual plant size (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the biomass of giant sacaton plants.

OTHER (1 STUDY) 

Germination/Emergence (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the emergence of giant sacaton plants."

query: What are the effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials?
relevant_summary:
Studies have found various effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials. Compost application increased soil organic matter levels, microbial biomass, and fruit yield in Italy (action 889), while high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss in Spain and the UK (action 891). 

Manures and agricultural composts showed multiple benefits including higher microbial biomass and respiration in three studies from the UK and USA (action 911), reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels in studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and USA, higher soil organic carbon levels in studies from India, Japan and UK, and increased crop yields in studies from India, Spain and Turkey (action 911).

Fresh plant material or crop residues increased microbial biomass in Belgium (action 910), reduced soil loss in Canada and India, and resulted in higher soil nitrogen levels and carbon storage across six studies from China, Denmark and India (action 910). Straw incorporation improved soil structure in India and increased barley yield in Denmark (action 910).

Green manures grown as soil amendments increased soil organic carbon and grain yields in studies from India and Pakistan (action 908). Mixed organic and inorganic amendments showed higher microbial biomass and activity in five controlled trials from China, India and Japan, reduced soil cracking in India, increased soil organic carbon levels, and improved maize yield in China (action 902).

query: Besides retaining crop residues, what other actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils?
relevant_summary: Multiple actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils. Adding mulch to crops (action 887) increases soil stability and reduces soil erosion on clay soils. Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards (action 1367) reduces soil erosion on clay soils compared to bare or tilled soils. Changing tillage practices to reduced or no-tillage systems (action 906) shows mixed results but generally reduces soil loss on clay soils when crop cover is present. Planting grass buffer strips/margins around fields (action 3982) helps reduce soil erosion at field edges. Using crop rotation (action 857) that includes forage crops reduces rainwater runoff and soil loss. Reducing grazing intensity (action 901) helps control compaction and reduces sediment erosion on clay soils. Amending soil with organic materials like fresh plant material or crop remains (action 910) and adding mulch can improve soil structure and reduce erosion susceptibility.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of planting grass margins around arable or pasture fields. Seventeen were in the UK, two were in each of Sweden, the Netherlands and the USA, and one was in each of China, France and Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (15 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (15 studies): One of two replicated, controlled studies in the UK found that 2-m grass margins had a greater species richness of butterflies than cropped field edges, but 6-m grass margins did not. The other study found that the species richness of butterflies was similar in grass margins and cropped field edges. Five replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in the USA, the UK and Italy found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a greater species richness or diversity of butterflies, macro-moths and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins, although one of these studies found that the species richness of macro-moths was similar in wide and conventional grass margins. Three of five replicated studies (including three randomized, controlled studies, one controlled study, and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a greater species richness of butterflies than standard grass margins. The other two studies found that farms with floristically enhanced margins (along with other enhanced agri-environment scheme (AES) options) had a similar species richness of butterflies and moths to farms with standard grass margins (along with basic AES options) and farms with no grass margins or other AES options. One site comparison study in Sweden found that grass margins sown with legumes or a clover and grass ley had a higher species richness of butterflies and moths than uncultivated margins, but less than a species-rich pasture. One replicated study in the Netherlands found that the species richness of butterflies increased over time after the establishment of grass margins. One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that disking or burning grass margins did not affect the species richness of butterflies.

POPULATION RESPONSE (22 STUDIES)

Abundance (21 studies): Three of four replicated, controlled studies in the UK found that grass margins had a higher abundance of butterflies than cropped field edges. The other study found that the abundance of gatekeepers on grass margins increased over four years after they were sown, but was only higher than cropped field edges at one of three farms after 2–4 years. Three of seven replicated, site comparison studies (including two paired studies) in the USA and the UK found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a higher abundance of habitat-sensitive butterflies, macro-moths and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins. Two of these studies, and the other four studies, found that the abundance of disturbance-tolerant butterflies, macro-moths generally, and pale shining brown moths specifically, was similar in wide and conventional grass margins. Four replicated studies (including two randomized, controlled studies, one controlled study, and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a higher abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins, uncultivated margins or margins sown with cereal crop. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the UK found that farms with floristically enhanced margins (along with other enhanced agri-environment scheme (AES) options) had a higher abundance of some butterflies and micro-moths, a similar abundance of macro-moths, but a lower abundance of other butterflies, than farms with standard grass margins (along with basic AES options) and farms with no grass margins or other AES options. One site comparison study in Sweden found that grass margins sown with legumes or a clover and grass ley had a higher abundance of butterflies and moths than uncultivated margins or a species-rich pasture. Two replicated, before-and-after studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in the Netherlands and the USA found that mowing, disking or burning grass margins did not affect the abundance of butterflies and moths generally, or diamondback moths specifically, but that disking increased the abundance of disturbance-tolerant butterflies. One replicated, paired, site comparison study in the UK found that field margins had a similar abundance of butterfly and moth caterpillars to beetle banks established in the middle of fields.
Survival (1 study): One site comparison study in China found that the survival of marsh fritillary caterpillars in grass margins around lightly cultivated fields was lower, but survival of egg clusters similar, to in uncultivated, grazed meadows.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in China found that grass margins around lightly cultivated fields were more likely to be occupied by marsh fritillary eggs and caterpillars than uncultivated, grazed meadows. One replicated, paired, site comparison study in France found that meadow brown butterflies used grass margins in a similar way to meadows."
}

query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different soil amendments for improving crop yields on farms in Asia?
relevant_summary: Evidence from Asia shows that mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments are effective for improving crop yields. Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China found increased maize yields in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments. Soil amendments with crops grown as green manures showed higher soil organic carbon and increased grain yields in studies from India and Pakistan. Fresh plant material and crop remains incorporation also improved yields, with a trial from the Philippines finding higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season. Adding manures and agricultural composts proved effective with four controlled, replicated studies from India, Spain and Turkey finding higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied. Bacterial and fungal amendments also showed positive results with two randomized, replicated trials from India and Turkey finding higher crop yields. Formulated chemical compounds (fertilizers) showed yield increases in trials from India and the Philippines where maize, wheat and rice yields increased with increased fertilizer application. Soil amendments with composts not otherwise specified increased fruit yield in Italy. The evidence indicates that organic amendments like manure, compost, and green manures, as well as mixed organic-inorganic combinations, are particularly effective for improving crop yields across various Asian countries including China, India, Pakistan, and the Philippines.

query: What actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils?
relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence from action documents, several effective actions can reduce nitrate loss from agricultural soils:

Growing cover crops in arable fields (Action ID: 1357) was found in four replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA to reduce nitrate leaching from soils compared to soils without cover crops. Growing cover crops when fields are empty (Action ID: 898) also showed reduced nitrate leaching in a randomized, replicated study from Denmark and Turkey.

Changing the timing of ploughing (Action ID: 712) demonstrated effectiveness in two replicated site comparison studies from Denmark and Norway, which found reduced nitrate leaching when ploughing was delayed until spring.

Amending the soil with formulated chemical compounds (Action ID: 909), specifically nitrification inhibitors, was effective in three of five replicated trials from New Zealand and the UK, which found reduced nitrate losses, though one study noted that the method of application influenced the effect.

Amending the soil with manures and agricultural composts (Action ID: 911) showed mixed results for nitrate leaching, with three randomized, replicated studies from Canada, Spain, the UK, and USA finding reduced nutrient loss when farmyard or poultry manure was applied, though one controlled replicated study found higher nitrate leaching.

Changing tillage practices (Action ID: 906) revealed mixed effects on nitrogen levels, with one controlled, replicated trial finding less carbon and nitrate in no-till compared to conventionally tilled soil, though conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate overall.

query: Which actions are most consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity?
relevant_summary:
Based on the comprehensive research findings, the actions most consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity are:

**Amending soil with organic materials** shows the strongest dual benefits. Adding fresh plant material or crop remains (Action 910) consistently increased soil organic carbon in six studies while also increasing microbial biomass (Action 887, Action 910). Similarly, amending soil with manures and agricultural composts (Action 911) increased soil organic carbon in four studies while also increasing microbial biomass and diversity in multiple trials.

**Crop residue retention** (Action 907) demonstrated positive effects for both outcomes, with higher soil organic carbon found in two randomized trials while also showing increased microbial biomass when crop residues were retained.

**Cover cropping** (Action 898) proved effective with increased soil carbon levels found in studies while also resulting in more diverse nematode communities and greater microbial biomass under different cover crop systems.

**Reduced or no-tillage systems** (Action 906) showed strong evidence for increasing soil organic carbon in twelve studies while four studies found increased numbers of soil animals and earthworms, plus higher microbial diversity and activity.

**Using mixed organic and inorganic amendments** (Action 902) provided dual benefits with four trials finding more organic carbon in soils while five controlled trials found higher microbial biomass and activity.

**Crop rotation** (Action 857) increased soil organic carbon in four studies while also increasing microbial numbers and diversity of different soil animals in trials.

These actions consistently demonstrate positive outcomes for both soil organic carbon sequestration and biodiversity enhancement across multiple peer-reviewed studies worldwide.

pH (6 studies): Four replicated studies (three randomized and controlled, one site comparison) from France, Italy, and Spain found similar pH levels in soils with organic or inorganic fertilizer. One replicated, controlled study from Italy found higher pH levels in soils with organic fertilizer, in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found lower pH levels in soils with organic fertilizer, in some comparisons.

Soil organisms (7 studies)

Microbial biomass (4 studies): Four replicated studies (three randomized and controlled, one site comparison) from France, Italy, and Spain found more microbial biomass in soils with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in some comparisons.
Other soil organisms (4 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found fewer bacteria in soils with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in one comparison. Greenhouse gases (11 studies)

Carbon dioxide (5 studies): Four replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and Spain found higher carbon dioxide emissions from plots with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found similar carbon dioxide emissions from plots with organic or inorganic fertilizer.
Methane (4 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found that more methane was absorbed by soils with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in some comparisons. Nitrous oxide (8 studies): Five replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found similar nitrous oxide emissions from plots with organic or inorganic fertilizer. One study from Italy found more organic matter, nutrients, and microbial biomass in plots fertilized with compost, compared to manure. query: As an alternative to adding compost, what other actions can improve the soil structure of silty-clay soils?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several alternatives to compost for improving silty-clay soil structure include: incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains like straw, which was found to improve soil structure in studies from India (action 910). Adding mulch to crops, such as straw or municipal compost, can increase soil stability and reduce erosion, with studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK showing increased soil stability and reduced runoff (action 887). Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure and nutrient retention, with three randomized studies from Denmark, Turkey and the UK finding improved soil structure and higher soil porosity (action 898). Changing tillage practices, such as switching from conventional tillage to no-tillage, can improve soil aggregation and stability, with seven replicated studies from Spain and the USA finding that untilled soils were more stable than tilled soils (actions 906, 1369). Using crop rotation, particularly including legumes and forage crops, can improve soil structure and increase water infiltration, with one replicated trial from Syria showing increased water infiltration when legumes were included in rotation (action 857). Retaining crop residues helps reduce soil erosion and improve water storage, with one review finding reduced water runoff, increased water storage and reduced soil erosion (action 907).

query: As an alternative to using chemical fertilizers to increase crop yield, what organic soil management practices are shown to be effective?
relevant_summary: Organic soil management practices that serve as effective alternatives to chemical fertilizers for increasing crop yield include: 1) Application of organic fertilizers such as manure and agricultural composts, which improved soil organic carbon levels and increased crop yields (Action ID 911, 1363). 2) Use of green manures grown specifically to amend soil, which increased soil organic carbon and grain yields (Action ID 908). 3) Incorporation of fresh plant material and crop residues, which improved soil organic carbon levels and increased crop yields (Action ID 910, 907). 4) Growing cover crops either beneath main crops or during field-empty periods, which enhanced soil organic matter, improved soil structure, increased nitrogen levels, and led to higher crop yields (Action ID 897, 898, 1345). 5) Implementing crop rotations, particularly those including legumes which increase soil organic carbon and water infiltration while supporting higher microbial diversity (Action ID 857, 900). Research shows these practices can maintain or improve crop yields compared to chemical fertilizers, with studies finding higher yields in plots with organic fertilizers in 4 out of 10 comparisons, while providing additional benefits such as reduced soil erosion, improved water retention, and enhanced biodiversity.

query: What actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction?
relevant_summary: Several actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction based on the evidence found. Reducing grazing intensity allows compacted soils to recover - one study from Australia found that excluding sheep for 2.5 years enabled compacted soils to recover. Amending soil with organic processing wastes or composts can improve soil structure and reduce soil loss, as demonstrated by a controlled trial from Spain that found applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure. Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains, such as straw incorporation, was found to improve soil structure in a study from India, and also reduced soil loss in a study from Canada. Growing cover crops when fields are empty can improve soil structure and nutrient retention, with studies from Denmark, Turkey, and the UK finding higher soil porosity, interconnectivity, and lower resistance in soil under cover crops. Using brash mats during harvesting can help avoid soil compaction, though no direct evidence was available for this practice. Reducing tillage intensity, including using no tillage or reduced tillage instead of conventional tillage, can improve soil aggregation and stability, with multiple studies finding that soils without tillage were more stable than tilled soils.

One of these studies also found that soil aggregates had lower water-stability in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found that water-stability was similar in plots with reduced tillage or conventional tillage. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found more large aggregates in soils with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in one of two comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found smaller aggregates in soils with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage. Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA found similar amounts of aggregation in soils with reduced tillage or conventional tillage.
Soil erosion (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Egypt found less erosion with less tillage (one pass with the tractor, compared to two), but found more erosion with shallower tillage, compared to deeper.

Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA found less carbon dioxide in soils with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some or all comparisons. Three controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found similar amounts of carbon dioxide in soils with reduced tillage or conventional tillage, in all comparisons.

Methane (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found similar amounts of methane in soils with reduced tillage or conventional tillage.

Implementation options (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Egypt found that less soil was lost in runoff water from plots that were tilled at slower tractor speeds."

query: What is the available evidence on how different soil amendments affect biodiversity in soils with a sandy loam texture?
relevant_summary: Evidence from multiple studies shows various effects of soil amendments on biodiversity in sandy loam soils. A mix of organic and inorganic amendments increased microbial biomass and activity in five controlled trials from China and India, with one trial also finding increased microbial diversity (Action 902). Adding bacteria or arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi resulted in higher microbial diversity in one randomized, replicated trial from India (Action 888). Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains increased microbial biomass in one randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium (Action 910). Manures and agricultural composts increased microbial biomass and respiration in three controlled, replicated studies from the UK and USA (Action 911). Municipal wastes and their composts showed mixed results in two controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the UK (Action 890). Organic processing wastes and their composts were tested in sandy loam soils, with one trial finding improved soil structure and reduced soil loss when applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure (Action 891). Cover crops grown in sandy loam soils resulted in more diverse nematode communities in one controlled, randomized, replicated experiment in Martinique (Action 898).

query: As an alternative to adding mulch, what actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils?
relevant_summary: Several actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils as alternatives to adding mulch. Amending the soil with manures and agricultural composts (Action 911) can improve soil structure and water retention by increasing soil organic matter and aggregation, with studies showing this can increase soil organic carbon and improve soil physical properties. Retaining crop residues (Action 907) reduces water runoff and increases water storage while also increasing soil organic carbon and nitrogen levels, making it particularly effective for sandy-loam soils. Growing cover crops or living mulches (Action 897) reduces soil erosion and can increase soil organic matter, with studies specifically on sandy loam and sandy soils showing these benefits. Changing tillage practices (Action 906) can improve the soil's ability to absorb water and increase soil water content through subsoiling, which is particularly relevant for drought conditions on sandy soils. Amending soils with organic processing wastes or composts (Action 891) can also improve soil structure on sandy loam soils, reducing soil loss and improving nutrient retention. These alternatives work by either adding organic matter to improve water-holding capacity, protecting the soil surface from evaporation, or modifying soil structure to enhance water infiltration and storage.

Soil organic matter: Fifteen studies from Canada, China, Europe, Morocco, and the USA measured effects of reduced tillage on soil organic matter content and nutrient retention. Of these, eight studies (including four replicated (two also randomized), two site comparisons (one also replicated) and one controlled) found maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure under reduced tillage. Four trials (including two replicated and two site comparison studies) found higher nutrient retention under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till compared to conventionally tilled soil, but conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial and one replicated trial found mixed effects of reduced tillage on soil nitrogen levels.
Yield: One replicated study from Canada found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage compared to conventional tillage, and one controlled, randomized, replicated study from the USA found higher yields when subsoiling was done. One randomized, replicated study from Portugal found no effect of tillage treatment on yield.

query: What are the wider soil health effects of amending soils with animal-derived products like manure or composts?
relevant_summary: Animal-derived soil amendments like manure and composts have demonstrated multiple beneficial effects on soil health. Studies have consistently shown higher microbial biomass and activity in soils amended with manure or compost, indicating improved soil biodiversity (actions 891, 911, 902). Soil organic carbon levels increase with manure application, as demonstrated in studies from India, Japan and the UK (action 911). These amendments also improve soil physical properties, with trials showing enhanced soil structure, larger soil aggregations, and reduced soil loss (actions 891, 911). Nutrient retention improves with manure and compost application, though one study noted potential for increased nutrient loss at high application rates (actions 891, 911). Water retention capacity increases, with research showing reduced water runoff following manure application (action 911). Crop yields consistently improve with manure and compost amendments across multiple studies from India, Spain and Turkey (action 911). When combined with inorganic fertilizers, manure amendments show even greater benefits for microbial activity and soil organic carbon (action 902).

query: What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of converting to low-input or organic farming systems?
relevant_summary:
The documented evidence shows mixed effects of organic farming conversion. For biodiversity outcomes, seven of eleven studies found organic arable farms had greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths and all moths than conventional farms, though some effects were context-dependent (occurring only in intensively managed landscapes, or in farms managed organically for <6 years but not 15-23 years) [Action ID: 3907]. Similar results were found for bat populations, with five of seven studies finding more bat species on organic farms, though five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity between organic and non-organic farms [Action ID: 961]. For wild bees, three studies showed higher abundance under organic farming while three found no difference [Action ID: 25].

Soil and ecosystem benefits included higher soil carbon levels in organically managed orchards compared to conventional management [Action ID: 895], and four studies finding higher numbers, diversity or activity of soil organisms under organic management [Action ID: 895]. However, one study found lower soil nutrients in organically managed soils [Action ID: 895].

Key drawbacks center on production and economics. Six studies measuring yields found mixed effects - one positive, one negative, one mixed, and three showing no or inconsistent effects [Action ID: 717]. One study found net profit increased only if produce received a premium, otherwise profit decreased [Action ID: 717]. Another found yields were lower in organically managed soils [Action ID: 895]. For organic fertilizers specifically, studies showed mixed effects on yields - some found higher yields with organic fertilizer, others found lower yields, and some found similar yields [Action ID: 1350].

Low-input systems showed benefits including higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in two studies [Action ID: 904], and stopping fertilizer inputs in grasslands increased plant species richness and invertebrate abundance in six studies [Action ID: 694]. However, one study found lower nutrient levels and yields in low-input systems [Action ID: 904].

query: In Europe, what alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure?
relevant_summary: In Europe, several alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure. Reduced tillage systems maintain or increase soil organic matter and improve soil structure compared to conventional ploughing (actions 906, 211, 3488, 1386, 2307). Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure and nutrient retention, with studies showing higher soil porosity, interconnectivity, and lower resistance (actions 898, 1345, 2304). Soil amendments using organic materials also enhance soil structure - incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains improves soil structure and creates larger soil aggregates (action 910), while amending soil with organic processing wastes or composts improves soil structure and reduces soil loss (action 891). Mixed organic and inorganic amendments are more effective at reducing soil cracks than fertilizers alone (action 902). These alternatives work by increasing soil organic carbon, enhancing microbial biomass, and creating better soil aggregation, which collectively improve soil structure without the need for conventional ploughing.

Sediments (0 studies)

query: Which actions are most effective for increasing soil microbial biomass?
relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence from multiple studies, the most effective actions for increasing soil microbial biomass are:

**Organic Amendments:**
- Adding compost to soil (Action 1362): Six studies found increased microbial biomass with compost application compared to no compost
- Amending soil with a mix of organic and inorganic amendments (Action 902): Multiple studies found higher microbial biomass and activity with manure and inorganic fertilizer combinations
- Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains (Action 910): One study found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added
- Retaining crop residues (Action 907): One study found higher microbial biomass when crop residues were retained

**Tillage Management:**
- Using reduced tillage (Actions 2307, 1371): Eleven replicated studies found more microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage
- Using no tillage as main cultivation method (Action 2306): Multiple studies found higher microbial biomass in soils without tillage compared to with tillage

**Cover Crops:**
- Growing cover crops or maintaining ground cover (Actions 2304, 1345, 898): Multiple studies found more microbial biomass with cover crops compared to bare/tilled soils
- Including cover crops in perennial systems: Four studies found increased microbial biomass with ground cover

**Crop Management:**
- Using crop rotations including legumes (Action 2305): Some studies showed microbial biomass increases with rotations vs. continuous crops

query: What are some of the most effective actions for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several effective methods for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land have been identified. Adding mulch to crops (action 887) has been shown in multiple studies to increase soil stability and reduce soil erosion and runoff, with five studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK demonstrating these benefits. Mulches also increased soil moisture and improved yields in replicated trials. Reducing grazing intensity (action 901) was found to help soil recovery from compaction and reduce sediment erosion, with studies showing that excluding grazing animals increased soil carbon and nitrogen levels while reducing soil phosphate loss and sediment erosion. Planting grass buffer strips and margins around fields (action 246) can help reduce runoff and soil loss, with nineteen studies from Europe showing benefits for biodiversity while helping to filter runoff. Using alley cropping (action 903), which involves intercropping with trees, was found to increase soil fungal diversity. These practices work by protecting soil surfaces, improving soil structure, reducing runoff velocity, and increasing ground cover to prevent soil particles from being washed or blown away.

Of these, one trial also showed that mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.
Nutrient loss: One replicated study from Nigeria found higher nutrient levels in continually cropped soil. 
Erosion: Five studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK (including one controlled, randomized, replicated trial, one randomized, replicated trial, two replicated (one also controlled), and one controlled trial) found that mulches increased soil stability, and reduced soil erosion and runoff. One trial found that some mulches are more effective than others.
Drought: Two replicated trials from India found that adding mulch to crops increased soil moisture.
Yield: Two replicated trials from India found that yields increased when either a live mulch or vegetation barrier combined with mulch was used.
 
SOIL TYPES COVERED: clay, fine loam, gravelly sandy loam, sandy, sandy-clay, sandy loam, sandy silt-loam, silty, silty loam."

query: On agricultural land, what are the documented benefits and drawbacks of amending soil with manures or municipal wastes?
relevant_summary:
Based on documented studies, manure application shows multiple benefits including higher microbial biomass and activity (action 911), reduced soil loss and water runoff when combined with other treatments (911), enhanced soil nutrient retention with higher nitrogen levels (911), increased soil organic carbon (911), improved soil organic matter and physical properties (911), and higher crop yields (911). However, manure application also documented drawbacks including higher nitrate leaching in some cases (911) and increased nutrient runoff with more dissolved organic carbon, nitrate, ammonium, phosphorus, and potassium being leached from soils (1378).

Municipal waste applications demonstrated benefits including greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid soils (890) and increased soil organic matter (1364). Drawbacks included mixed results in some applications (890), increased nitrate levels in soil (1364), and higher carbon dioxide emissions from soils with added sewage sludge compared to untreated soils (1364). Implementation variations showed digested sewage sludge resulted in more soil nitrate compared to composted or thermally dried forms (1364).

query: What actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils?
relevant_summary: Several actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils. Adding organic amendments is highly effective, including composts and organic processing wastes (action 891), fresh plant material or crop remains (action 910), and manures with agricultural composts (action 911), which improve soil structure, increase soil organic carbon, create larger soil aggregates, and enhance nutrient retention. Growing cover crops when fields are empty (action 898) improves soil structure by increasing soil porosity and interconnectivity while reducing compaction. Changing tillage practices (action 906) can reduce soil compaction, though results vary between studies. Adding mulch to crops (action 887) increases soil stability and reduces erosion. Amending soil with a mix of organic and inorganic amendments (action 902) effectively reduces crack size in dry clay soils. Growing green manures (action 908) increases soil organic carbon in clay loam soils. Adding gypsum to soil (action 1708) can improve soil conditions for planting. These actions have been tested on various clay and clay-loam soil types and demonstrate measurable improvements in soil physical properties.

  "action_id": "910",
  "action_title": "Amend the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: One randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added.
Compaction: One study from India found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated. One before-and-after trial from the UK found that incorporating straw residues by discing (reduced tillage) did not improve anaerobic soils (low oxygen levels) in compacted soils.
Erosion: Two randomized, replicated studies from Canada and India measured the effect of incorporating straw on erosion. One found straw addition reduced soil loss, and one found mixed effects depending on soil type.
Nutrient loss: Four replicated studies from Belgium, the UK and the USA (one also controlled, one also randomized, and two also controlled and randomized) reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied, but mixed results when processed wastes were added. One also found reduced nitrate leaching when straw was incorporated. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Soil organic carbon: Six studies from China, Denmark and India measured the effect of incorporating plant material into the soil. All (including one replicated, two randomized, replicated studies, one controlled, randomized, replicated studies and one controlled before-and-after site comparison) found higher carbon levels when plant material was added. One found higher carbon levels when straw was applied along with NPK fertilizers. One also found larger soil aggregates. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Yield: One replicated trial from Denmark found higher barley yield when straw was incorporated. One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
 
Soil types covered: clay, clay loam, fine loam, loam/sandy loam, loamy sand, sandy, sandy clay loam, sandy loam, sandy-silt, silt loam, silty, silty-clay."
}

{
  "action_id": "898",
  "action_title": "Grow cover crops when the field is empty",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: One controlled, randomized, replicated experiment in Martinique found that growing cover crops resulted in more diverse nematode communities. One replicated trial from the USA found greater microbial biomass under ryegrass compared to a ryegrass/vetch cover crop mix.
Soil structure: Three randomized, replicated studies from Denmark, Turkey and the UK found that growing cover crops improved soil structure and nutrient retention. One trial found higher soil porosity, interconnectivity and lower resistance in soil under cover crops, and one found reduced nitrate leaching.
Soil organic carbon: One replicated study from Denmark and one review based mainly in Japan found increased soil carbon levels under cover crops. One study also found soil carbon levels increased further when legumes were included in cover crops.
Soil organic matter: One replicated study from Denmark and three controlled, randomized, replicated studies from Australia and the USA measured the effect of growing cover crops. Three found increased nitrogen levels under cover crops, three found increased carbon, and one found increased nitrates. One trial showed that they increased regardless of whether those crops were legumes or not. Two studies from Europe (including one controlled, replicated trial) found no marked effect on soil organic matter levels.
Yield: One replicated trial from the USA found higher tomato yield from soils which had been under a ryegrass cover crop.
 
SOIL TYPES COVERED: clay, loam, sandy clay, sandy-loam, silty-clay, silty-loam."
}

{
  "action_id": "906",
  "action_title": "Change tillage practices",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity loss: Eleven studies from Canada, Europe, Mexico, or the USA measured effects of reduced tillage on soil animals or microbes. Of these, four (including three replicated trials (three also randomized and one also controlled)) found more microbes, more species of earthworm, or higher microbe activity under reduced tillage. One replicated trial found increased numbers of soil animals and earthworms under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found mixed effects on microbe diversity depending on time of sampling. Two, (including one controlled, replicated trial) found no effect of reduced tillage on earthworm activity or microbe activity.
Compaction: Five studies from Australia, Canada, and Europe measured the effect of controlled traffic and reduced tillage on compacted soils. Of these, two (including one before-and-after trial and one replicated trial) found reduced compaction and subsequent effects (reduced water runoff, for example) under controlled traffic, and one also found that crop yields increased under no-tillage. Three replicated trials, including one site comparison study, found higher compaction under reduced tillage. 
Drought: Three replicated trials from Europe and India (one also randomized) found the size of soil cracks decreased, and ability of soil to absorb water and soil water content increased with conventional ploughing and sub-soiling. 
Erosion: Nine replicated trials from Brazil, Europe, India, Nigeria and the USA, and one review showed mixed results of tillage on soil erosion. Seven trials (one also controlled and randomized) showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage compared to conventional ploughing. One trial showed no differences between tillage systems, but demonstrated that across-slope cultivation reduced soil loss compared to up-and-downslope cultivation. Two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss in the absence of crop cover.
Soil organic carbon: Twelve studies from Australia, Canada, China, Europe, Japan and the USA compared the effect of no-tillage and conventionally tilled systems on soil organic carbon. All (including two randomized, five replicated, two randomized, replicated, and one controlled, randomized, replicated) found higher soil organic carbon in soils under a no-tillage or reduced tillage system compared to conventionally tilled soil. One review showed that no-tillage with cover cropping and manure application increases soil organic carbon. One randomized, replicated trial from Spain found greater soil organic carbon in conventionally tilled soil. One replicated trial from Canada found no effect of tillage on soil carbon.
Soil organic matter: Fifteen studies from Canada, China, Europe, Morocco, and the USA measured effects of reduced tillage on soil organic matter content and nutrient retention. Of these, eight studies (including four replicated (two also randomized), two site comparisons (one also replicated) and one controlled) found maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure under reduced tillage. Four trials (including two replicated and two site comparison studies) found higher nutrient retention under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till compared to conventionally tilled soil, but conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial and one replicated trial found mixed effects of reduced tillage on soil nitrogen levels.
Yield: One replicated study from Canada found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage compared to conventional tillage, and one controlled, randomized, replicated study from the USA found higher yields when subsoiling was done. One randomized, replicated study from Portugal found no effect of tillage treatment on yield.
 
SOIL TYPES COVERED: anthrosol, calcareous silt loam, chalky, clay, clay loam, fine sandy loam, loam, loamy-clay, loam - sandy loam, loam – silt-loam, loamy sand, loamy silt, non-chalky clay, sandy, sandy clay loam, sandy loam, sandy silt-loam, silt loam, silty, silty-clay, silty clay loam, silty loam."
}

{
  "action_id": "887",
  "action_title": "Add mulch to crops",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: Three replicated trials from Canada, Poland and Spain (including one also controlled, one also randomized and one also controlled and randomized) showed that adding mulch to crops (whether shredded paper, municipal compost or straw) increased soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity and activity. Of these, one trial also showed that mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.
Nutrient loss: One replicated study from Nigeria found higher nutrient levels in continually cropped soil. 
Erosion: Five studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK (including one controlled, randomized, replicated trial, one randomized, replicated trial, two replicated (one also controlled), and one controlled trial) found that mulches increased soil stability, and reduced soil erosion and runoff. One trial found that some mulches are more effective than others.
Drought: Two replicated trials from India found that adding mulch to crops increased soil moisture.
Yield: Two replicated trials from India found that yields increased when either a live mulch or vegetation barrier combined with mulch was used.
 
SOIL TYPES COVERED: clay, fine loam, gravelly sandy loam, sandy, sandy-clay, sandy loam, sandy silt-loam, silty, silty loam."
}

{
  "action_id": "902",
  "action_title": "Amend the soil using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: Five controlled trials from China and India (four also randomized and replicated), and one study from Japan found higher microbial biomass and activity in soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers. Manure alone also increased microbial biomass. One trial found increased microbial diversity.
Erosion: One controlled, replicated trial from India found that mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
SOC loss: Four controlled, randomized, replicated trials and one controlled trial from China and India found more organic carbon in soils with mixed fertilizers. Manure alone also increased organic carbon. One trial also found more carbon in soil amended with inorganic fertilizers and lime.
SOM loss: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China and India found more nutrients in soils with manure and inorganic fertilizers. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial from China found inconsistent effects of using mixed manure and inorganic fertilizers.
Yield: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China found increased maize Zea mays yield in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments.
SOIL TYPES COVERED: clay, clay loam, sandy-loam, silt clay loam, silty-loam."
}

{
  "action_id": "911",
  "action_title": "Amend the soil with manures and agricultural composts",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity loss: Three controlled, replicated studies from the UK and USA found higher microbial biomass when manure or compost was applied, and higher microbial respiration when poultry manure was applied.
Erosion: One controlled, randomized, replicated study from India found lower soil loss and water runoff with manure application in combination with other treatments.
Nutrient management: Four studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and the USA measured the effect of a variety of manure types on soil nutrient levels. Of these, three randomized, replicated studies (two also controlled) found reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels when farmyard or poultry manure was applied. One also found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure (rather than poultry manure or slurry) was applied in winter rather than autumn. One controlled replicated study found higher nitrate leaching.
Soil organic carbon: Four studies (including three controlled, replicated studies (one also randomized) and a review) from India, Japan and the UK found higher carbon levels when manures were applied.
Soil organic matter: One controlled, randomized, replicated study from Turkey found higher organic matter, larger soil aggregations and a positive effect on soil physical properties when manure and compost were applied. Two studies from Denmark and Germany found no effect of manure on organic matter levels.
Yield: Four controlled, replicated studies (including three also randomized) from India, Spain and Turkey found higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied. One study found higher yields when manure were applied in combination with cover crops.
Soil types covered: Clay loam, fine sandy-silty loam, loam, loamy, sandy loam, sandy clay loam, silty loam, and sandy silt loam."
}
